verses.text: Jehoshaphat rested with his fathers, and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David. Then Jehoram his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: No significant difference from the original; 'rested with his fathers' is maintained as a traditional biblical phrase.

verses.text: He had brothers—the sons of Jehoshaphat: Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariah, Michael, and Shephatiah. All these were the sons of King Jehoshaphat of Israel.
verses.comment: Both Azariahs appear in the Hebrew; maintained here for faithfulness.

verses.text: Their father gave them many gifts of silver, gold, and valuable things, along with fortified cities in Judah; but the kingdom he gave to Jehoram, because he was the firstborn.
verses.comment: Maintains the distinction between gifts and inheritance of the kingdom as in the original.

verses.text: When Jehoram had taken control of his father’s kingdom and established his power, he killed all his brothers with the sword, as well as some of the leaders of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Took control’ modernizes ‘was risen up’; violence against his brothers and leaders left clear.

verses.text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned eight years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: No significant change. Age and reign duration are preserved.

verses.text: He walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab did, for he had married a daughter of Ahab. He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Ways of the kings of Israel’ is retained as the literal phrase.

verses.text: Yet the LORD was not willing to destroy the house of David because of the covenant he had made with David, since he had promised to give a lamp to him and to his descendants forever.
verses.comment: ‘Lamp’ kept as a Hebraic idiom for dynasty continuing.

verses.text: During Jehoram’s reign, Edom revolted from under Judah’s authority and set up their own king.
verses.comment: ‘Revolted’ is a contemporary rendering of ‘made a revolt’; kept ‘set up their own king’ for clarity.

verses.text: So Jehoram crossed over with his officers and all his chariots. He got up by night and struck the Edomites, who had surrounded him and the chariot commanders.
verses.comment: ‘Got up by night’ for ‘rose up by night’. Relates the battle faithfully.

verses.text: So Edom has been in revolt against Judah’s rule to this day. Libnah also rebelled at that time, because Jehoram had abandoned the LORD, the God of his ancestors.
verses.comment: 'to this day' kept as Hebrew idiom; ‘abandoned’ as modern rendering for ‘forsaken’.

verses.text: Moreover, Jehoram built high places on the hills of Judah, and caused the people of Jerusalem to commit spiritual prostitution, leading Judah astray.
verses.comment: ‘Spiritual prostitution’ translates the Heb. ‘whoredom’; idiom explained for modern clarity.

verses.text: Then a letter from Elijah the prophet came to Jehoram, saying, 'This is what the LORD, the God of your ancestor David, says: Because you have not walked in the ways of your father Jehoshaphat or of Asa king of Judah,
verses.comment: Faithfully rendered; note Elijah’s letter, unique to Chronicles.

verses.text: but have walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, and have made Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem commit spiritual prostitution, just as the house of Ahab led Israel to do, and have killed your brothers, your own father's sons, who were better than you,
verses.comment: 'Spiritual prostitution' again clarifies Hebrew idiom; 'better than you' kept for literal faithfulness.

verses.text: therefore the LORD is about to strike your people, your sons, your wives, and all your possessions with a great calamity.
verses.comment: ‘Calamity’ for ‘plague’; preserved collective objects for accuracy.

verses.text: And you yourself will have a severe sickness, a disease of your intestines, until your bowels come out, because of the illness, day after day.'
verses.comment: ‘Day after day’ renders Hebrew ‘by day and by night’; ‘bowels come out’ is literal.

verses.text: Then the LORD stirred up against Jehoram the spirit of the Philistines and of the Arabs who lived near the Cushites.
verses.comment: ‘Stirred up’ kept as literal; ‘who lived near the Cushites’ interprets the Heb. wording.

verses.text: They came up against Judah, invaded it, and carried away all the possessions found in the king’s palace, and also his sons and wives, so that no son was left to him except Jehoahaz, his youngest.
verses.comment: ‘Carried away,’ not ‘carried off captive,’ clarifies; Jehoahaz as youngest is maintained.

verses.text: After all this, the LORD struck Jehoram in his intestines with a disease that could not be cured.
verses.comment: ‘Disease that could not be cured’ modernizes ‘incurable disease’.

verses.text: After two years, his intestines came out because of his disease, and he died in great pain. His people did not make a fire in his honor, like the fires for his ancestors.
verses.comment: ‘Great pain’ modernizes ‘sore diseases’; fire custom kept clear.

verses.text: He was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned eight years in Jerusalem. He departed with no one’s regret. They buried him in the city of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.
verses.comment: ‘Departed with no one’s regret’ renders ‘without being desired’; burial detail kept.
